fields.label_text:
7  ROSEBOWL
London, 1912-13
Mark of Omar Ramsden (1873-1939) and Alwyn Carr 
Inscribed on the base: OMAR RAMSDEN ET ALWYN CARR ME FECERUNT MCMXII.  The sides are chased and embossed with the signs of the zodiac and engraved with the inscription:  THE ANCIENT ZODIAC PICTURES STILL THE NEVER ENDING SONG OF HUMAN LIVES, WHICH LEAF, BUD AND BLOSSOMS AS THE FLOWERS, THE SUNSHINE, SHADOW, PLEASURE, PAIN AND WRONG, ARE BUT THE UNITS OF THE QUICKLY PASSING HOURS.

In a letter dated 27 November, 1975, Mrs Campbell-Voullaire states that her grandmother, Mary Elizabeth Laidlaw commissioned this bowl amongst several other pieces by Ramsden & Carr.  Mrs Laidlaw was interested in the Arts and Crafts movement; her husband however was not.  She may have encountered Ramsden & Carr through the sculptor March who executed a bust of Mrs Campbell-Voullaire, or through Edward Spencer of the Artificiers’ Guild.
Mrs M. Campbell-Voullaire Gift
M.285-1975

fields.descriptive_line: Rose bowl and cover, silver, London hallmarks for 1912-13, mark of Ramsden and Carr.

7  ROSEBOWL
London, 1912-13
Mark of Omar Ramsden (1873-1939) and Alwyn Carr 
Inscribed on the base: OMAR RAMSDEN ET ALWYN CARR ME FECERUNT MCMXII.  The sides are chased and embossed with the signs of the zodiac and engraved with the inscription:  THE ANCIENT ZODIAC PICTURES STILL THE NEVER ENDING SONG OF HUMAN LIVES, WHICH LEAF, BUD AND BLOSSOMS AS THE FLOWERS, THE SUNSHINE, SHADOW, PLEASURE, PAIN AND WRONG, ARE BUT THE UNITS OF THE QUICKLY PASSING HOURS.

In a letter dated 27 November, 1975, Mrs Campbell-Voullaire states that her grandmother, Mary Elizabeth Laidlaw commissioned this bowl amongst several other pieces by Ramsden & Carr.  Mrs Laidlaw was interested in the Arts and Crafts movement; her husband however was not.  She may have encountered Ramsden & Carr through the sculptor March who executed a bust of Mrs Campbell-Voullaire, or through Edward Spencer of the Artificiers’ Guild.
Mrs M. Campbell-Voullaire Gift
M.285-1975 [18/02/2000]
fields.public_access_description: This rose bowl is one of several pieces commissioned from Ramsden & Carr by the donor's grandmother, Mrs Mary Eliza Laidlaw, an enthusiastic supporter of the Arts and Crafts movement.  Omar Ramsden and Alwyn Carr met while students at the Sheffield School of Art and and after graduating in 1899, moved to London and set up a partnership which lasted until 1918.
fields.exhibition_history: The Silver Galleries (Victoria and Albert Museum)
fields.bibliography: Shirley Bury in <u>British Art and Design,1900-1960</u>, ed. Carol Hogben, London,Victoria and Albert Museum, 1983, pp.46-47 ill. ISBN. 0905209575

Acquisition RF: 75 / 1436
Gift - Mrs M Campbell-Voullaire
le Presbytere
Majerolles par Najac, Avignon 12270, France
In a letter dated 27 November, 1975, Mrs Campbell-Voullaire states that her grandmother, Mary Elizabeth Laidlaw commissioned this bowl amongst several other pieces by Ramsden & Carr.  Mrs Laidlaw was interested in the Arts and Crafts movement; her husband however was not.  She may have encountered Ramsden & Carr through the sculptor March who executed a bust of Mrs Campbell-Voullaire, or through Edward Spencer of the Artificiers' Guild.

Neg._No: HC 2981
fields.historical_context_note:
EDWARDIAN SILVER

Despite relentless commercial pressures and a conservative public which favoured historicist revivals, innovations did emerge in European silverware in the early years of the 20th century, prior to the First World War.  The cup and cover (1909-10) by Child & Child of Thurloe Place, South Kensington, in a revived, German Renaissance manner illustrates the prevailing mainstream taste for historicism while the Painter and Stainers’ Cup designed by C.R. Ashbee for Harris Heal (1900-01) is a very contemporary and subtle restatement of a 17th century design and epitomises the essence of the British Arts and Crafts movement.  

By 1900, Ashbee and his Guild of Handicraft had a achieved a stylistic maturity.  For a while the Guild even showed a modest profit but events were moving swiftly.  In the 1890s the work produced by the Guild struck a fresh and original note.  By the 1900s, Ashbee was to witness others adapting his ideas and extending them further.  The workshops of Henry Wilson, Nelson Dawson and Edward Spencer of the Artificer’s Guild, Omar Ramsden and in Denmark,  Michelsen and Georg Jensen began to produce work that was richer and more self assured than the austere, products of the Guild of Handicraft.  These firms successfully popularised the Arts and Crafts philosophy and occasionally incorporated Art Nouveau tendencies.  The retailer A.L. Liberty of Regent Street with his Cymric range of silver and jewellery was the amongst the most successful and all remained commercially viable long after the demise of the Guild in 1908.

(Graphic panel:  the Silver Galleries)
